results.title: The American road
results.brief_description: Produced to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Ford Motor Company, this film traces the development of American highways over the last 50 years. It tells the story of man’s method of transportation and how it has influenced his life, business, health and recreation. Includes archival footage of the early days of Henry Ford’s factory, such as the creation of the first assembly line.

results.title: The American revolution
results.brief_description: Portrays highlights of the American Revolution from the Boston Tea Party to the surrender of Cornwallis to Washington at Yorktown. Includes scenes depicting the battles of Lexington and Concord, the attack on Fort Ticonderoga and the campaigns led by General Washington. No other credits available.

results.title: American music: from folk to jazz and pop
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Donald, Stephen Fleischman and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: Looks at the “musical explosion” by tracing the roots of popular music or jazz in American history. Studies the African and European roots in New Orleans jazz and gospel songs in hillbilly folk songs and dances, showing many of the actual oletime as well as recent performers who gave American popular music its first expression, and developed it into the internationally recognised jazz of today.

results.title: American Indians of today
results.brief_description: Surveys the life of American Indians in the United States today. Home for most Indians is on a reservation, where they may be engaged in farming or cattle raising. Some tribes have found it difficult to adapt themselves after centuries of semi-nomadic life. Other tribes have advanced to local self-government. Includes scenes of life on the San Carlos Apache Reservation in Arizona, the Sioux in South Dakota, the Seneca in New York.

results.title: America on the edge of abundance
results.brief_description: Traces America’s snowballing history as an affluent society and looks at the dilemma which abundance brings. A land of abounding factory production and consumption, where success is measured by material standards. America underwent a revolution from an agricultural to an manufacturing society. Now a second revolution looms, to an automated society. What will this mean to the nation, and how individuals will accept a society in which a minority of people can manage the nation’s work, is discussed.

results.title: America abroad
results.creator_credit: Michael Ingrams, Peter Hunt, Associated-Rediffusion and Intertel
results.brief_description: Approximately 2,000,000 United States citizens live and work abroad, in some 70 nations which benefit from American aid. Four of these countries and some of these United States citizens are in Cambodia, Vietnam, Pakistan and Ghana.

results.title: America. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Paul Killiam, Saul J. Turell and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
D.W. Griffith’s epic historical spectacle of the American Revolution, shot on the actual locations, and staged with almost documentary realism. The cast is headed by Neil Hamilton, Lionel Barrymore, Carol Dempster and Louis Wolhiem. This is an edited version of the original film which was made in 1909.

results.title: Amenu's child
results.creator_credit: Sean Graham and Gold Coast Film Unit
results.brief_description: Told in the idiom of an African folk story, this film attempts to encourage native women to seek medical assistance from the local health clinics instead of from witch doctors. Points out that African women are learning the value of modern medicine, but one, Foriwa, was a sceptic and only her child’s death convinced her that the medicine man and the fetish priest, from whom she sought help, had neither the power nor the knowledge to cure her baby. Stresses the importance of practising modern methods of feeding and sanitation as a preventative measure for illness.

results.title: Amelia and the angel
results.creator_credit: Ken Russell and Anthony G. Evans
results.brief_description: A surreal fairy tale about a little girl in search of a pair of angel’s wings. The story is set in a background of London scenes, South Kensington, Earl’s Court, the Albert Memorial and Rotten Row. In the course of her search she visits a junk shop down the road, a jumble stall and finally tracks down a perfect pair of wings in a crazy artist’s studio. An interesting contrast is provided between the high-quality location photography and the surreal intrusions by a collection of fairy-tale characters. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: The Amazing newborn
results.creator_credit: Patricia E Rambasek and Maureen Hack
results.brief_description: Shows how normal infants aged 1-7 days can see and have visual preferences, turn their heads in response to spoken words, mimic and move in rhythm to parental voices. It also shows the six states of consciousness first observed by Peter Wolff.
